CS-433 (Machine Learning)

1. Linear Regression

yn≈x~nTw~y_n \approx \mathbf{\tilde x}_n^T \mathbf{\tilde w}yn​≈x~nT​w~﻿, where x~n∈RD+1\mathbf{\tilde x}_n \in \R^{D+1} x~n​∈RD+1﻿ is the feature vector with a 1 in front (adding a constant) and w~∈RD+1\mathbf{\tilde w} \in \R^{D+1} w~∈RD+1﻿ the weight vector for predicting label yny_nyn​﻿

2. Loss functions

Desirable: symmetric around 0, penalise large and very large mistakes similarly

  • MSE(w)=1N∑n=1Nen2=1N∑n=1N[yn−fw(xn)]2\text{MSE(w)} = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{n=1}^{N} e_n^2 = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{n=1}^{N} [y_n - f_\mathbf{w}(\mathbf{x}_n)]^2MSE(w)=N1​∑n=1N​en2​=N1​∑n=1N​[yn​−fw​(xn​)]2﻿ → not good for outliers
  • MAE(w)=1N∑n=1N∣en∣=1N∑n=1N∣yn−fw(xn)∣\text{MAE(w)} = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{n=1}^{N} |e_n| = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{n=1}^{N} |y_n - f_\mathbf{w}(\mathbf{x}_n)|MAE(w)=N1​∑n=1N​∣en​∣=N1​∑n=1N​∣yn​−fw​(xn​)∣﻿ → good for outliers

Convexity

Function h(u)h(u)h(u)﻿ is convex if for any u,v∈RDu, v \in \R^Du,v∈RD﻿ and for any 0≤λ≤10 \leq \lambda \leq 1 0≤λ≤1﻿ we have:

A strictly convex function has a unique global minimum. For convex functions, every local minimum is a global minimum. Sums of convex functions and compositions of convex functions with convex non-decreasing functions are convex.

3. Optimisation

Find w∗∈RD\mathbf{w}^* \in \R^Dw∗∈RD﻿ such that it is minwL(w)\text{min}_\mathbf{w} \mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w})minw​L(w)﻿

Grid search: nn n﻿ parameters per dimension → nDn^DnD﻿ evaluations and no guarantee to find minimum

Gradient descent: ∇L(w):=[∂L(w)∂w1,...,∂L(w)∂wD]∈RD\nabla \mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w}) := \left[ \frac{\partial \mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w})}{\partial w_1}, ..., \frac{\partial \mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w})}{\partial w_D} \right] \in \R^D∇L(w):=[∂w1​∂L(w)​,...,∂wD​∂L(w)​]∈RD﻿

  • w(t+1):=w(t)−γ∇L(w(t))\mathbf{w}^{(t+1)}:=\mathbf{w}^{(t)}-\gamma \nabla \mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w^{(t)}})w(t+1):=w(t)−γ∇L(w(t))﻿
  • Linear MSE: e=y−Xw\mathbf{e = y-Xw}e=y−Xw﻿
    • L(w)=12Ne⊤e\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w}) = \frac{1}{2N}\mathbf{e}^\top\mathbf{e}L(w)=2N1​e⊤e﻿
    • ∇L(w)=−1NX⊤e\nabla \mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w}) = -\frac{1}{N}\mathbf{X}^\top\mathbf{e}∇L(w)=−N1​X⊤e﻿
    • Global complexity O(ND)\mathcal{O}(ND)O(ND)﻿

SGD:

  • w(t+1):=w(t)−γ∇Ln(w(t))\mathbf{w}^{(t+1)}:=\mathbf{w}^{(t)}-\gamma \nabla \mathcal{L}_n(\mathbf{w^{(t)}})w(t+1):=w(t)−γ∇Ln​(w(t))﻿
  • Cheap but unbiased estimate of the gradient
  • Global complexity O(D)\mathcal{O}(D)O(D)﻿

Mini-batch SGD:

  • g:=1∣B∣∑n∈B∇Ln(w(t))g:=\frac{1}{|B|} \sum_{n \in B}\nabla \mathcal{L}_n(\mathbf{w^{(t)}})g:=∣B∣1​∑n∈B​∇Ln​(w(t))﻿, B is a subset of the N samples
  • w(t+1):=w(t)−γg\mathbf{w}^{(t+1)}:=\mathbf{w}^{(t)}-\gamma gw(t+1):=w(t)−γg﻿

Subgradient descent:

  • Convexity for differentiable functions: L(u)≥L(w)+∇L(w)⊤(u−w)\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{u}) \geq \mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w})+\nabla \mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w})^\top(\mathbf{u}-\mathbf{w})L(u)≥L(w)+∇L(w)⊤(u−w)﻿
  • Subgradient g∈∂Lg \in \partial \mathcal{L}g∈∂L﻿: L(u)≥L(w)+g⊤(u−w)\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{u}) \geq \mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w})+g^\top(\mathbf{u}-\mathbf{w})L(u)≥L(w)+g⊤(u−w)﻿

Projected gradient descent:

  • Intersections of convex sets are convex
  • Projection on convex constraint set C\mathcal{C}C﻿ after each gradient descent step
  • Turn into unconstrained problem: penalty function if not in C\mathcal{C}C﻿
4. Least squares

Gram matrix X⊤X∈RD×D\mathbf{X}^\top \mathbf{X}\in \R^{D\times D}X⊤X∈RD×D﻿. Closed form for optimal w∗\mathbf{w}^*w∗﻿ given by X⊤Xw∗=X⊤y\mathbf{X}^\top \mathbf{X} \mathbf{w}^*=\mathbf{X}^\top \mathbf{y}X⊤Xw∗=X⊤y﻿. The Gram matrix is invertible iff X∈RN×D\mathbf{X} \in \R^{N \times D}X∈RN×D﻿ has full column rank. Complexity is O(ND2+D3)\mathcal{O}(ND^2+D^3)O(ND2+D3)﻿

  • L2L_2L2​﻿-regularisation closed form with λ′=2Nλ\lambda' = 2N \lambdaλ′=2Nλ﻿: (X⊤X+λ′Id)w∗=X⊤y(\mathbf{X}^\top \mathbf{X}+\lambda'\mathbf{I}_d) \mathbf{w}^*=\mathbf{X}^\top \mathbf{y}(X⊤X+λ′Id​)w∗=X⊤y﻿
  • Eigenvalues of (X⊤X+λ′I)(\mathbf{X}^\top \mathbf{X}+\lambda'\mathbf{I})(X⊤X+λ′I)﻿ are at least λ′\lambda'λ′﻿
5. Maximum Likelihood

Maximising the likelihood instead of minimising the loss. Our data is yn=xn⊤w+ϵny_n = \mathbf{x}^\top_n \mathbf{w} + \epsilon_nyn​=xn⊤​w+ϵn​﻿, where ϵn\epsilon_nϵn​﻿ is a random variable (e.g. Gaussian) that is iid across nnn﻿.

Log likelihood LLL(w):=log⁡p(y∣X,w)=∑n=1Np(yn∣xn,w)\mathcal{L}_{LL}(\mathbf{w}) := \log p(\mathbf{y}|\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{w}) = \sum_{n=1}^N p(y_n|\mathbf{x}_n, \mathbf{w})LLL​(w):=logp(y∣X,w)=∑n=1N​p(yn​∣xn​,w)﻿

6. Regularisation

Penalise complex models: minwL(w)+Ω(w)\text{min}_\mathbf{w} \mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w}) + \Omega(\mathbf{w})minw​L(w)+Ω(w)﻿

  • L2L_2L2​﻿-regularisation (ridge): Ω(w)=λ∣∣w∣∣22\Omega(\mathbf{w})=\lambda||\mathbf{w}||_2^2Ω(w)=λ∣∣w∣∣22​﻿
    • Gradient is 2w2\mathbf{w}2w﻿
    • Model small in magnitude
  • L1L_1L1​﻿-regularisation (lasso): Ω(w)=λ∣∣w∣∣1\Omega(\mathbf{w})=\lambda||\mathbf{w}||_1Ω(w)=λ∣∣w∣∣1​﻿
    • Gradient is sign(w)\text{sign}(\mathbf{w})sign(w)﻿
    • Model is sparse
  • L0L_0L0​﻿-regularisation (lasso): Ω(w)=#(w≠0)\Omega(\mathbf{w})=\#(\mathbf{w} \neq 0)Ω(w)=#(w=0)﻿
  • Shrinkage, dropout, weight decay, early stopping
7. Generalisation, model selection and validation

Generalisation gap: how far is the test from the true error?

Given KKK﻿ different models fKf_KfK​﻿, an iid test set Stest∼D\text{S}_\text{test}\sim \mathcal{D}Stest​∼D﻿ (that follows the true data distribution) and a loss L∈[a,b]\mathcal{L} \in [a, b]L∈[a,b]﻿:

To remove the absolute value, put 2 in front of the square root and take the values of KKK﻿ for which the functions fk^f_{\hat k}fk^​﻿ and fk∗f_{k^*}fk∗​﻿ have the smallest empirical or true risk respectively.

Hoeffding inequality ∀ϵ≥0\forall \epsilon \geq 0∀ϵ≥0﻿, Θn\Theta_nΘn​﻿ are the loss functions

Hoeffding lemma ∀s≥0\forall s \geq 0∀s≥0﻿, and RV X∈[a,b]\mathbf{X} \in [a,b]X∈[a,b]﻿ with E[X]=0\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{X}] = 0E[X]=0﻿

K-fold cross validation returns an unbiased estimate of the generalisation-error and its variance

8. Bias-variance decomposition

Bias and variance of the prediction considering that the input sample SSS﻿ is a random variable

Noise → Strict lower bound, as independently random and impossible to predict (1st term)

Bias → how far off in general the model’s predictions are from the correct value (2nd term)

Variance → How much the predictions for a given point vary between realisations of the training set (3rd term)

9. Classification

The optimal classification performance is the Bayers classifier :=g∗=argmin⁡gLD(g):= g_* = \text{arg} \min_g \mathcal{L}_\mathcal{D}(g) :=g∗​=argming​LD​(g)﻿

g∗(x)=argmax⁡y∈{−1,1}P(Y=y∣X=x)g_*(x) = \text{arg} \max_{y \in \{ -1, 1\}} \mathbb{P}(Y=y|X=x) g∗​(x)=argmaxy∈{−1,1}​P(Y=y∣X=x)﻿

Loss functions

  • (0-1 Loss) → L(y,y′)=1y≠y′\mathcal{L}(y, y')=1_{y \neq y'}L(y,y′)=1y=y′​﻿ which is 1 if y≠y′y \neq y'y=y′﻿ and 0 if y=y′y = y'y=y′﻿
  • True risk for classification for a predictor ggg﻿ → LD(g)=ED[1Y≠g(X)]=PD[Y≠g(X)]\mathcal{L}_\mathcal{D}(g)=\mathbb{E}_\mathcal{D}[1_{Y \neq g(X)}] = \mathbb{P}_\mathcal{D}[Y \neq g(X)]LD​(g)=ED​[1Y=g(X)​]=PD​[Y=g(X)]﻿
  • Convex and continuous losses (η=yx⊤w)\eta = yx^\top w)η=yx⊤w)﻿:
    • quadratic loss :=(1−η)2:= (1-\eta)^2:=(1−η)2﻿ → symmetric but only works for [−∞,2][-\infty, 2][−∞,2]﻿
    • hinge loss :=[1−η]+:= [1-\eta]_+:=[1−η]+​﻿ → penalty on [−∞,2][-\infty, 2][−∞,2]﻿ (prediction wrong or not confident)
    • logistic loss :=ln⁡(1+e−η)ln⁡(2):= \frac{\ln(1+e^{-\eta})}{\ln(2)}:=ln(2)ln(1+e−η)​﻿ → always penalising

Non-parametric

Approximate conditional distribution P(Y=y∣X=x)\mathbb{P}(Y=y|X=x) P(Y=y∣X=x)﻿ via local averaging (KNN)

Parametric

Approximate true distribution D\mathcal{D}D﻿ via training data → minimise empirical risk (ERM)

Instead of learning function g:X→{−1,1}g: X\rightarrow \{-1, 1\}g:X→{−1,1}﻿, we learn a continuous function hhh﻿ and predict with g(x)=sign(h(x))g(x) = \text{sign}(h(x))g(x)=sign(h(x))﻿. We replace the 0-1 loss by a convex and continuous surrogate ϕ\phiϕ﻿:

In the over-parameterisation (n<<d)(n<<d)(n<<d)﻿ regime, the training data is well fit with a regressor → a good regressor can be used as a classifier

10. Logistic regression

Logistic function σ(η):=eη1+eη\sigma(\eta):=\frac{e^\eta}{1+e^\eta}σ(η):=1+eηeη​﻿. We have 1−σ(η)=11+eη1-\sigma(\eta) = \frac{1}{1+e^\eta}1−σ(η)=1+eη1​﻿ and σ′(η):=σ(η)(1−σ(η))\sigma'(\eta):=\sigma(\eta)(1-\sigma(\eta))σ′(η):=σ(η)(1−σ(η))﻿

Robust against outliers and unbalanced data. If σ(x)>12\sigma(x)>\frac{1}{2}σ(x)>21​﻿, then for a>0,σ(ax)>12a > 0, \sigma(ax)>\frac{1}{2}a>0,σ(ax)>21​﻿

Optimality:

  • linear for y∈{1,0}y \in \{1, 0\}y∈{1,0}﻿: w∗=argmin⁡wL:=1N∑n=1N−ynxn⊤w+log⁡(1+exn⊤w)w_* = \text{arg} \min_w \mathcal{L} := \frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^N-y_n x_n^\top w + \log (1+e^{x_n^\top w})w∗​=argminw​L:=N1​∑n=1N​−yn​xn⊤​w+log(1+exn⊤​w)﻿
  • generic hhh﻿ for y∈{1,0}y \in \{1, 0\}y∈{1,0}﻿: L(y,h(x))=−yh(x)+log⁡(1+eh(x))\mathcal{L}(y, h(x)) = -yh(x) + \log (1+e^{h(x)})L(y,h(x))=−yh(x)+log(1+eh(x))﻿
  • generic hhh﻿ for y∈{−1,1}y \in \{-1, 1\}y∈{−1,1}﻿: L(y,h(x))=log⁡(1+e−yh(x))\mathcal{L}(y, h(x)) = \log (1+e^{-yh(x)})L(y,h(x))=log(1+e−yh(x))﻿

Gradient:

  • linear problem convex and ∇L(w)=1NX⊤(σ(Xw)−y))\nabla \mathcal{L}(w)=\frac{1}{N} \mathbf{X}^\top(\sigma(\mathbf{X}w)-y))∇L(w)=N1​X⊤(σ(Xw)−y))﻿

Hessian:

  • ∇2L(w)=1NX⊤SX\nabla^2 \mathcal{L}(w)=\frac{1}{N} \mathbf{X}^\top S \mathbf{X}∇2L(w)=N1​X⊤SX﻿, where S=diag[σ(xn⊤w)(1−σ(xn⊤w))]≥0S=\text{diag}[\sigma(x_n^\top w)(1-\sigma(x_n^\top w))] \geq 0S=diag[σ(xn⊤​w)(1−σ(xn⊤​w))]≥0﻿
  • Hessian is psd → loss is convex
  • Newton’s method: w(t+1):=w(t)−γ(t)∇2L(w(t))−1∇L(w(t))\mathbf{w}^{(t+1)}:=\mathbf{w}^{(t)}-\gamma^{(t)} \nabla^2 \mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w^{(t)}})^{-1}\nabla \mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w^{(t)}})w(t+1):=w(t)−γ(t)∇2L(w(t))−1∇L(w(t))﻿

When data is linearly separable, weights w→∞w \rightarrow \inftyw→∞﻿ even though all points are well separated. Solution: add L2L_2 L2​﻿ regularisation

11. Support vector machines (SVM)

We consider y∈{−1,1}y \in \{-1, 1\}y∈{−1,1}﻿. Margin of a hyperplane :=min⁡n≤N∣w⊤xn∣:= \min_{n \leq N} |w^\top x_n|:=minn≤N​∣w⊤xn​∣﻿

Hard SVM - 3 equivalent formulations

  1. max⁡w,∣∣w∣∣=1min⁡n≤N∣w⊤xn∣ \max_{w, ||w||=1} \min_{n \leq N} |w^\top x_n|maxw,∣∣w∣∣=1​minn≤N​∣w⊤xn​∣﻿ such that ∀n,ynxn⊤w≥0\forall n, y_n x_n^\top w \geq 0∀n,yn​xn⊤​w≥0﻿
  1. max⁡M∈R,w,∣∣w∣∣=1M \max_{M \in \R, w, ||w||=1} MmaxM∈R,w,∣∣w∣∣=1​M﻿ such that ∀n,ynxn⊤w≥M\forall n, y_n x_n^\top w \geq M∀n,yn​xn⊤​w≥M﻿
  1. min⁡w12∣∣w∣∣2 \min_w \frac{1}{2}||w||^2minw​21​∣∣w∣∣2﻿ such that ∀n,ynxn⊤w≥1\forall n, y_n x_n^\top w \geq 1∀n,yn​xn⊤​w≥1﻿ → M=1∣∣w∣∣M = \frac{1}{||w||}M=∣∣w∣∣1​﻿

Soft SVM - non linearly separable data

Maximise margin while allowing some constraints to be violated

[z]+=max⁡(0,z)=max⁡α∈[0,1]αz[z]_+ = \max(0, z)=\max_{\alpha \in [0,1]} \alpha z[z]+​=max(0,z)=maxα∈[0,1]​αz﻿. Continuous but non-smooth → subgradients

Dual formulation

Define a function G(w,α)G(w, \alpha) G(w,α)﻿ such that min⁡wL=min⁡wmax⁡αG(w,α)\min_w \mathcal{L}=\min_w \max_\alpha G(w, \alpha)minw​L=minw​maxα​G(w,α)﻿. GG G﻿ is convex in www﻿ and concave in α\alphaα﻿.

Primal problem: min⁡wmax⁡αG(w,α)\min_w \max_\alpha G(w, \alpha)minw​maxα​G(w,α)﻿

Dual problem: max⁡αmin⁡wG(w,α)\max_\alpha \min_w G(w, \alpha)maxα​minw​G(w,α)﻿

where w(α)=1λNX⊤Yαw(\alpha)=\frac{1}{\lambda N} \mathbf{X}^\top\mathbf{Y}\alphaw(α)=λN1​X⊤Yα﻿ and Y=diag(y)\mathbf{Y} = \text{diag}(\mathbf{y})Y=diag(y)﻿. YXX⊤Y\mathbf{YXX}^\top\mathbf{Y} YXX⊤Y﻿ is psd and only depends on kernel matrix.

  • αn=0\alpha_n = 0αn​=0﻿ if xnx_nxn​﻿ is on the right side, outside of the margin (1−ynxn⊤w<0)1-y_nx_n^\top w < 0)1−yn​xn⊤​w<0)﻿
  • αn∈[0,1]\alpha_n \in [0,1]αn​∈[0,1]﻿ if xnx_nxn​﻿ is on the right side and on the margin (1−ynxn⊤w=0)1-y_nx_n^\top w = 0)1−yn​xn⊤​w=0)﻿
  • αn=1\alpha_n = 1αn​=1﻿ if xnx_nxn​﻿ is on the inside the margin or on the wrong side (1−ynxn⊤w>0)1-y_nx_n^\top w > 0)1−yn​xn⊤​w>0)﻿
  • Points for which αn>0\alpha_n > 0αn​>0﻿ are called support vectors (model only depends on support vectors)

12. Nearest Neighbour Classifiers

KNN can be used for:

  • regression: for point xxx﻿, find the KKK﻿ closest points yky_kyk​﻿ (the KKK﻿ points in the neighbourhood) → the estimate is then given by fK(x)=1K∑Kykf_K(x)=\frac{1}{K} \sum^Ky_kfK​(x)=K1​∑Kyk​﻿
  • classification: get KKK﻿ closest neighbours of xxx﻿ and count how many are in groups aaa﻿ or bbb﻿ → assign group of point xxx﻿ depending on the majority group in the neighbourhood

Small KKK﻿ → complex decision boundary → low bias, high variance (overfitting)

Large KKK﻿ → when k=Nk=Nk=N﻿ prediction is constant → high bias, low variance

Curse of dimensionality: NNN﻿ i.i.d. points uniform in [0,1]d→P(∃xi∈□d)=1−(1−rd)N[0,1]^d \rightarrow \mathbb{P}(\exist x_i \in \square^d) = 1-(1- r^d)^N[0,1]d→P(∃xi​∈□d)=1−(1−rd)N﻿

Generalisation bound for 1-NN: X×Y=[0,1]d×{0,1}\mathbf{X} \times \mathbf{Y} = [0,1]^d \times \{0,1\} X×Y=[0,1]d×{0,1}﻿

  • Bayes classifier minimises L\mathcal{L}L﻿ over all classifiers f∗(x)=1η(x)≥12f_*(x)= 1_{\eta(x)\geq\frac{1}{2}}f∗​(x)=1η(x)≥21​​﻿ where

    η(x)=P(Y=1∣X=x)\eta(x)=\mathbb{P}(Y=1|X=x)η(x)=P(Y=1∣X=x)﻿
  • Bayes risk: L(f∗)=P(f∗(X)≠Y)=EX∼DX[min⁡{η(x),1−η(x)}]\mathcal{L}(f_*)=\mathbb{P}(f_*(X)\neq Y)=\mathbb{E}_{X\sim \mathcal{D_X}}[\min\{\eta(x), 1-\eta(x)\}]L(f∗​)=P(f∗​(X)=Y)=EX∼DX​​[min{η(x),1−η(x)}]﻿
  • Assumption: ∃c≥0\exist c \geq 0∃c≥0﻿, ∀x,x′∈X\forall x, x' \in X∀x,x′∈X﻿: ∣η(x)−η(x′)∣≤c∣∣x−x′∣∣2|\eta(x)-\eta(x')| \leq c||x-x'||_2∣η(x)−η(x′)∣≤c∣∣x−x′∣∣2​﻿ (Lipschitz with ct. c)
    → nearby points are likely to share the same label
  • Claim: EStrain[L(fStrain)]≤2L(f∗)+4cdN−1d+1\mathbb{E}_{S_{train}}[\mathcal{L}(f_{S_{train}})] \leq 2 \mathcal{L}(f_*) + 4c \sqrt{d}N^{-\frac{1}{d+1}}EStrain​​[L(fStrain​​)]≤2L(f∗​)+4cd​N−d+11​﻿
  • To achieve constant error we need N∝dd+12N \propto d^{\frac{d+1}{2}}N∝d2d+1​﻿
  • P(Y′≠Y)≤2min⁡{η(x),1−η(x)}+c∣∣x−x′∣∣\mathbb{P}(Y'\neq Y) \leq 2\min\{\eta(x), 1- \eta(x)\}+c||x-x'||P(Y′=Y)≤2min{η(x),1−η(x)}+c∣∣x−x′∣∣﻿
  • Let pk=P(X∈Boxk)p_k = \mathbb{P}(X \in \text{Box}_k)pk​=P(X∈Boxk​)﻿, then sample XXX﻿ has probability 1−(1−pk)N1-(1-p_k)^N 1−(1−pk​)N﻿ to have a neighbour in StrainS_{train}Strain​﻿ in the box at distance ≤dϵ\leq \sqrt{d}\epsilon≤d​ϵ﻿ (ϵ\epsilonϵ﻿ is Box edge lenght) and probability (1−pk)N(1-p_k)^N (1−pk​)N﻿ to not have a neighbour in the box (closest neighbour ≤d\leq \sqrt{d}≤d​﻿)
  • E[∣∣X−nbh(X)∣∣]≤∑kpk[(1−pk)Nd+(1−(1−pk)N)dϵ]\mathbb{E}[||X-\text{nbh}(X)||] \leq \sum_k p_k[(1-p_k)^N \sqrt{d} + (1-(1-p_k)^N) \sqrt{d}\epsilon]E[∣∣X−nbh(X)∣∣]≤∑k​pk​[(1−pk​)Nd​+(1−(1−pk​)N)d​ϵ]﻿
  • Local averaging methods aim to approximate the Bayes’ predictor directly by approximating the conditional distribution p^(y∣x)\hat p(y|x)p^​(y∣x)﻿. For N→∞N \rightarrow \inftyN→∞﻿, 1-NN is competitive with Bayes’ classifier
13. Kernel trick

Covariance matrix X⊤X∈RD×D\mathbf{X}^\top \mathbf{X}\in \R^{D\times D}X⊤X∈RD×D﻿, Kernel matrix XX⊤∈RN×N \mathbf{X}\mathbf{X}^\top\in \R^{N\times N}XX⊤∈RN×N﻿

→ Ridge regression w∗=1NX⊤(1NXX⊤+λIN)−1y\mathbf{w}^*=\frac{1}{N}\mathbf{X}^\top (\frac{1}{N} \mathbf{X} \mathbf{X}^\top+\lambda\mathbf{I}_N)^{-1} \mathbf{y}w∗=N1​X⊤(N1​XX⊤+λIN​)−1y﻿ complexity O(DN2+N3)\mathcal{O}(DN^2+N^3)O(DN2+N3)﻿

Representer theorem: For any loss L\mathcal{L}L﻿ there exists α∗∈RN\alpha_* \in \R^Nα∗​∈RN﻿, where R(w)R(w)R(w)﻿ is any increasing regularisation term, such that

Kernel trick: Kernel function κ(x,x′)=ϕ(x)⊤ϕ(x′)\kappa(x, x') = \phi(x)^\top \phi(x')κ(x,x′)=ϕ(x)⊤ϕ(x′)﻿ → computation of linear classifiers in high-dimensional space ϕ(xn)∈Rd~\phi(x_n) \in \R^{\tilde d}ϕ(xn​)∈Rd~﻿ without computing directly in that space. Prediction with kernel: y=ϕ(x)⊤w∗=∑n=1Nκ(x,xn)α∗ny=\phi(x)^\top w_* = \sum_{n=1}^N \kappa(x, x_n)\alpha_{*n}y=ϕ(x)⊤w∗​=∑n=1N​κ(x,xn​)α∗n​﻿ (non-linear prediction in XXX﻿ space but linear in feature space ϕ(X)\phi(X)ϕ(X)﻿)

  1. Linear kernel: κ(x,x′)=x⊤x′→ϕ(x)=x\kappa(x, x') = x^\top x' \rightarrow \phi(x)=xκ(x,x′)=x⊤x′→ϕ(x)=x﻿
  1. Quadratic kernel: κ(x,x′)=(xx′)2→ϕ(x)=x2\kappa(x, x') = (x x')^2 \rightarrow \phi(x)=x^2κ(x,x′)=(xx′)2→ϕ(x)=x2﻿ (for x,x′∈Rx, x' \in \Rx,x′∈R﻿)
  1. Polynomial kernel: κ(x,x′)=(x1x1′+x2x2′+x3x3′)2\kappa(x, x') = (x_1 x_1'+x_2 x_2'+x_3 x_3')^2 κ(x,x′)=(x1​x1′​+x2​x2′​+x3​x3′​)2﻿

    →ϕ(x)=[x12,x22,x32,2x1x2,2x1x3,2x2x3]∈R6\rightarrow \phi(x)=[x_1^2, x_2^2, x_3^2, \sqrt{2}x_1x_2, \sqrt{2}x_1x_3, \sqrt{2}x_2x_3] \in \R^6→ϕ(x)=[x12​,x22​,x32​,2​x1​x2​,2​x1​x3​,2​x2​x3​]∈R6﻿ (for x,x′∈R3x, x' \in \R^3x,x′∈R3﻿)
  1. Radial basis function (RBF) kernel:
    1. x,x′∈Rdx, x' \in \R^dx,x′∈Rd﻿: κ(x,x′)=e−(x−x′)⊤(x−x′)\kappa(x, x') = e^{-(x-x')^\top(x-x')}κ(x,x′)=e−(x−x′)⊤(x−x′)﻿
    1. x,x′∈Rx, x' \in \Rx,x′∈R﻿: κ(x,x′)=e−(x−x′)2→ϕ(x)=e−x2(...,2k2xkk!,...)\kappa(x, x') = e^{-(x-x')^2} \rightarrow \phi(x)=e^{-x^2}(..., \frac{2^{\frac{k}{2}}x^k}{\sqrt{k!}},...)κ(x,x′)=e−(x−x′)2→ϕ(x)=e−x2(...,k!​22k​xk​,...)﻿ for 0≤k<∞0\leq k<\infty0≤k<∞﻿

Building new kernels from existing ones:

  • κ(x,x′)=ακ1(x,x′)+βκ2(x,x′)\kappa(x, x') = \alpha \kappa_1(x, x') + \beta \kappa_2(x, x')κ(x,x′)=ακ1​(x,x′)+βκ2​(x,x′)﻿ is a kernel for α,β≥0\alpha, \beta \geq 0α,β≥0﻿
  • κ(x,x′)=κ1(x,x′)κ2(x,x′)\kappa(x, x') = \kappa_1(x, x') \kappa_2(x, x')κ(x,x′)=κ1​(x,x′)κ2​(x,x′)﻿ is a kernel

Mercer’s condition: ∃ϕ(x)\exist \phi(x)∃ϕ(x)﻿ such that κ(x,x′)=ϕ(x)⊤ϕ(x′)\kappa(x, x') = \phi(x)^\top \phi(x')κ(x,x′)=ϕ(x)⊤ϕ(x′)﻿ iff

  1. kernel function is symmetric: κ(x,x′)=κ(x′,x)\kappa(x, x') = \kappa(x', x) κ(x,x′)=κ(x′,x)﻿ ∀x,x′\forall x, x'∀x,x′﻿
  1. kernel matrix is psd: κ(x,x′)≥0\kappa(x, x') \geq 0κ(x,x′)≥0﻿

14. Neural Networks

Learn non-linear function fNN(x)f_{NN}(x)fNN​(x)﻿ to transform xxx﻿ into a good feature representation for predictions.

Multi-layer perceptron (MLP) structure

Network with LLL﻿ hidden layers with KLK_LKL​﻿ neurons each. The output of hidden layer lll﻿ is

x(l)=f(l)(x(l−1)):=ϕ((W(l))⊤x(l−1)+b(l))x^{(l)}=f^{(l)}(x^{(l-1)}):=\phi((\mathbf{W}^{(l)})^\top x^{(l-1)}+b^{(l)})x(l)=f(l)(x(l−1)):=ϕ((W(l))⊤x(l−1)+b(l))﻿, where the weights W(l)\mathbf{W}^{(l)}W(l)﻿ and biases b(l)b^{(l)}b(l)﻿ are learnable → O(K2L)\mathcal{O}(K^2L)O(K2L)﻿ learnable parameters. The global function y=f(x(0))y=f(x^{(0)})y=f(x(0))﻿ is the composition f=f(L+1)∘f(L)∘...∘f(1)f=f^{(L+1)} \circ f^{(L)} \circ ... \circ f^{(1)}f=f(L+1)∘f(L)∘...∘f(1)﻿

  • Inference: h(x)=f(x)⊤w(L+1)+b(L+1)h(x) = f(x)^\top w^{(L+1)}+b^{(L+1)}h(x)=f(x)⊤w(L+1)+b(L+1)﻿
    • Regression → h(x)h(x)h(x)﻿
    • Binary classification with y∈{−1,1}y\in \{-1,1\}y∈{−1,1}﻿ → sign(h(x))\text{sign}(h(x))sign(h(x))﻿
    • Multi-Class classification y∈{1,...,K}y\in \{1,...,K\}y∈{1,...,K}﻿ → argmax⁡c∈{1,...,K}h(x)c\text{arg} \max_{c\in \{1,...,K\}}h(x)_cargmaxc∈{1,...,K}​h(x)c​﻿
  • Training
    • Regression → L(y,h(x))=(h(x)−y)2\mathcal{L}(y,h(x))=(h(x)-y)^2L(y,h(x))=(h(x)−y)2﻿
    • Binary classification with → L(y,h(x))=ln⁡(1+exp⁡(−yh(x)))\mathcal{L}(y,h(x))=\ln(1+\exp(-yh(x)))L(y,h(x))=ln(1+exp(−yh(x)))﻿
    • Multi-Class classification → L(y,h(x))=−ln⁡(eh(x)y∑i=1Keh(x)i)\mathcal{L}(y,h(x))=-\ln(\frac{e^{h(x)_y}}{\sum_{i=1}^K e^{h(x)_i}})L(y,h(x))=−ln(∑i=1K​eh(x)i​eh(x)y​​)﻿
  • Activation functions:
    sigmoid
    ϕ(x)=σ(x)\phi(x) = \sigma(x)ϕ(x)=σ(x)﻿, ReLU ϕ(x)=[x]+=max⁡{0,x}\phi(x) = [x]_+ = \max\{0, x\}ϕ(x)=[x]+​=max{0,x}﻿, GeLU ϕ(x)≈x⋅σ(1.702x)\phi(x) \approx x\cdot\sigma(1.702x)ϕ(x)≈x⋅σ(1.702x)﻿

Representation power

  • All sufficiently smooth function can be approximated by a one-hidden-layer NN (l2l_2l2​﻿ norm):

    ∫∣x∣≤r(f(x)−fn(x))2dx≤(2Cr)2n\int_{|x|\leq r} (f(x)-f_n(x))^2dx\leq\frac{(2Cr)^2}{n}∫∣x∣≤r​(f(x)−fn​(x))2dx≤n(2Cr)2​﻿, CCC﻿→ the smaller, the smoother fff﻿
  • A NN with sigmoid activation and at most two hidden layers can approximate well a smooth function in l1l_1l1​﻿-norm
    1. Approximate the function integral in the Riemann sense by a sum of kk k﻿ rectangles
    1. Represent each rectangle using two nodes in the hidden layer of a neural network

      h(ϕ(w(x−a))−ϕ(w(x−b)))h(\phi(w(x-a))-\phi(w(x-b))) h(ϕ(w(x−a))−ϕ(w(x−b)))﻿
    1. Compute the sum of all nodes in the hidden layer (considering appropriate weights and signs) to get the final output → NN with one hidden layer containing 2k2k2k﻿ nodes for a
      Riemann sum with
      kkk﻿ rectangles
  • l∞l_\inftyl∞​﻿ approximation result: fff﻿ continuous on [c,d][c,d][c,d]﻿. ∀ϵ≥0\forall \epsilon \geq0∀ϵ≥0﻿, it exists piecewise linear (pwl) continuous qqq﻿ such that sup⁡x∈[c,d]∣f(x)−q(x)∣≤ϵ\sup_{x\in[c,d]} |f(x)-q(x)| \leq \epsilonsupx∈[c,d]​∣f(x)−q(x)∣≤ϵ﻿
    1. pwl qqq﻿ can be written as combination of ReLU q(x)=a~1x+b~1+∑i=2ma~i(x−b~1)+q(x)=\tilde a_1x+\tilde b_1 + \sum_{i=2}^m \tilde a_i(x-\tilde b_1)_+q(x)=a~1​x+b~1​+∑i=2m​a~i​(x−b~1​)+​﻿
    1. qqq﻿ can be implemented as a one-hidden-layer NN with ReLU activation

Training (SGD) - Backpropagation

Searching min⁡wi,j(l),bi(l)L(f)\min_{w_{i,j}^{(l)}, b_i^{(l)}} \mathcal{L}(f)minwi,j(l)​,bi(l)​​L(f)﻿ using SGD→ non-convex

Forward pass: O(K2L)\mathcal{O}(K^2L)O(K2L)﻿

  • x(0)=xn∈Rdx^{(0)}=x_n \in \R^dx(0)=xn​∈Rd﻿
  • z(l)=(W(l))⊤x(l−1)+b(l)z^{(l)}=(\mathbf{W}^{(l)})^\top x^{(l-1)}+b^{(l)}z(l)=(W(l))⊤x(l−1)+b(l)﻿
  • x(l)=ϕ(z(l))x^{(l)} = \phi(z^{(l)})x(l)=ϕ(z(l))﻿

Backward pass: O(K2L)\mathcal{O}(K^2L)O(K2L)﻿

  • δ(L+1)=z(L+1)−yn\delta^{(L+1)} = z^{(L+1)}-y_nδ(L+1)=z(L+1)−yn​﻿
  • δ(l)=(W(l+1)δ(l+1))⊙ϕ′(z(l))\delta^{(l)}=(\mathbf{W}^{(l+1)}\delta^{(l+1)}) \odot \phi'(z^{(l)})δ(l)=(W(l+1)δ(l+1))⊙ϕ′(z(l))﻿

Derivatives:

  • ∂Ln∂wi,j(l)=δj(l)xi(l−1)\frac{\partial \mathcal{L}_n}{\partial w_{i,j}^{(l)}} = \delta_j^{(l)}x_i^{(l-1)}∂wi,j(l)​∂Ln​​=δj(l)​xi(l−1)​﻿
  • ∂Ln∂bj(l)=δj(l)\frac{\partial \mathcal{L}_n}{\partial b_j^{(l)}} = \delta_j^{(l)}∂bj(l)​∂Ln​​=δj(l)​﻿

Parameter initialisation: vanishing/exploding gradient → He initialisation. For ReLU networks, initialise weights as N(0,2/K⋅IK)\mathcal{N}(0, \sqrt{2/K} \cdot \mathbf{I}_K)N(0,2/K​⋅IK​)﻿

Normalisation layers: dynamically stabilise training process → faster convergence

  • Batch normalisation: zˉn(l)=zn(l)−μB(l)(σB(l))2+ϵ\bar z_n^{(l)}= \frac{z_n^{(l)}-\mu_B^{(l)}}{\sqrt{(\sigma_B^{(l)})^2+\epsilon}}zˉn(l)​=(σB(l)​)2+ϵ​zn(l)​−μB(l)​​﻿ (ϵ≈0\epsilon \approx 0ϵ≈0﻿ for numerical stability)
    Learnable parameters to reverse normalisation:
    z^n(l)=γ(l)⊙zˉn(l)+β(l)\hat z_n^{(l)}=\gamma^{(l)} \odot \bar z_n^{(l)}+ \beta^{(l)}z^n(l)​=γ(l)⊙zˉn(l)​+β(l)﻿

    Prediction should not depend on batch → estimate μ^=E[μ]\hat \mu = \mathbb{E}[\mu]μ^​=E[μ]﻿ and σ^=E[σ]\hat \sigma = \mathbb{E}[\sigma] σ^=E[σ]﻿ and use for inference. Requires sufficiently large batches for good approximations

  • Layer normalisation: Same but summing over KKK﻿ to get μ\muμ﻿ and σ\sigmaσ﻿
    Batch independent → use same normalisation for training and inference

Convolutional nets

Image size W×HW\times HW×H﻿. Convolution xn,m(1)=∑k,lfk,l⋅xn−k,m−l(0)x_{n,m}^{(1)}=\sum_{k,l}f_{k,l}\cdot x_{n-k,m-l}^{(0)}xn,m(1)​=∑k,l​fk,l​⋅xn−k,m−l(0)​﻿ where fff﻿ is a local filter with learnable weights. xn,m(1)x_{n,m}^{(1)}xn,m(1)​﻿ only depends on values of x(0)x^{(0)}x(0)﻿ close to (n,m)(n,m)(n,m)﻿ → sparsely connected

  • Padding: for borders, use zero padding or valid padding (reduces dimensionality)
  • Multiple channels: possible to use CCC﻿ channels (filters) on one input
  • Pooling: down-sampling
    • max pooling: returns max value of feature portion covered by kernel
    • average pooling: returns average value of feature portion covered by kernel
  • Hyperparameters: pooling/convolution size/type/stride. Generally: W,H↘W,H \searrow W,H↘﻿ and C↗C \nearrowC↗﻿
  • Weight sharing: back-propagation ignoring weights are shared and summing gradients of edges sharing weights

Regularisation

Residual networks: skip connections around some layers Y=R(X)+X\mathbf{Y}=R(\mathbf{X})+\mathbf{X}Y=R(X)+X﻿: lower training loss

Data augmentation: generate new data with same labels by corrupting existing data → robust

Weight decay: l2l_2 l2​﻿ regularise weights without regularising biases. No direct regularisation effect (scale invariance) but training dynamics differ

Dropout: at each training step, retain nodes in layer (l)(l) (l)﻿ with probability p(l)p^{(l)}p(l)﻿ and scale by p(l)p^{(l)}p(l)﻿ (for inference, where all nodes are used). Variance not preserved! → works poorly with normalisation

15. Transformers

Transformer f:sequence→sequencef:sequence \rightarrow sequence f:sequence→sequence﻿. Applicable across any modality (everything can be a token), good for long-range dependencies in text, self-attention scales quadratically but highly parallelisable

Input Transformations

Input→tokens∈RDInput \rightarrow tokens \in \R^DInput→tokens∈RD﻿

  • for each word in text→ token ID → vector in RD\R^DRD﻿
  • for each patch in image → flatten ∈RF\in \R^{F}∈RF﻿ → multiply by embedding matrix W∈RF×D\mathbf{W} \in \R^{F\times D}W∈RF×D﻿

Transformer block

tokens∈RD→tokens∈RDtokens \in \R^D \rightarrow tokens \in \R^Dtokens∈RD→tokens∈RD﻿

  • Attention: A:tokens→tokensA:tokens \rightarrow tokensA:tokens→tokens﻿
    • Query tokens Q∈RTout×DKQ \in \R^{T_{out}\times D_K}Q∈RTout​×DK​﻿

      Key tokens K∈RTin×DKK \in \R^{T_{in}\times D_K}K∈RTin​×DK​﻿
    • mixes info between tokens ~ weighted average with weights pi,jp_{i,j}pi,j​﻿ based on how similar qiq_iqi​﻿ and kjk_jkj​﻿ are: P=softmax(QK⊤DK)P=\text{softmax}\left(\frac{QK^\top}{\sqrt{D_K}}\right)P=softmax(DK​​QK⊤​)﻿, where softmax(x)i=exi∑jexj\text{softmax}(\mathbf{x})_i=\frac{e^{x_i}}{\sum_j e^{x_j}}softmax(x)i​=∑j​exj​exi​​﻿
  • Self-Attention: T=Tin=ToutT=T_{in}=T_{out}T=Tin​=Tout​﻿, X∈RT×DX\in \R^{T \times D}X∈RT×D﻿
    • Queries Q=XWQ∈RT×DKQ = XW_Q \in \R^{T\times D_K}Q=XWQ​∈RT×DK​﻿

      Keys K=XWK∈RT×DKK = XW_K\in \R^{T\times D_K}K=XWK​∈RT×DK​﻿

      Values V=XWV∈RT×DV = XW_V\in \R^{T\times D}V=XWV​∈RT×D﻿
    • Output Z=softmax(XWQWK⊤X⊤DK)XWV=softmax(QK⊤DK)VZ=\text{softmax}\left(\frac{X W_Q W_K^\top X^\top}{\sqrt{D_K}}\right) X W_V = \text{softmax}\left(\frac{QK^\top}{\sqrt{D_K}}\right) VZ=softmax(DK​​XWQ​WK⊤​X⊤​)XWV​=softmax(DK​​QK⊤​)V﻿
    • Run HHH﻿ self-attention heads in parallel and linearly combine the outputs
  • MLP: mixes information within tokens MLP(X)=φ(XW1)W2\text{MLP}(X)=\varphi(XW_1)W_2MLP(X)=φ(XW1​)W2​﻿ ← learned WWW﻿
  • Other blocks: Layer Normalisation, Skip connections + add positional embedding!

Output Transformations

tokens∈RD→outputtokens \in \R^D \rightarrow outputtokens∈RD→output﻿

  • Simple: linear or small MLP, task dependent (classification/multiple outputs)
16. Adversarial machine learning

Adversarial risk of classifier fff﻿: Rϵ(f)=ED[max⁡x^,∣∣x^−X∣∣≤ϵ1f(x^)≠Y]R_\epsilon(f)=\mathbb{E}_\mathcal{D}\left[ \max_{\hat x, ||\hat x- X|| \leq \epsilon} 1_{f(\hat x)\neq Y} \right]Rϵ​(f)=ED​[maxx^,∣∣x^−X∣∣≤ϵ​1f(x^)=Y​]﻿ → optimise the input xxx﻿ to get maximum error (easy if already misclassified, else need to optimise). Use smooth classification loss ℓ\ellℓ﻿ instead of (0-1): output before classification is ggg﻿, classify with sign(g(x))\text{sign}(g(x))sign(g(x))﻿. Then the objective is equivalent to max⁡x^,∣∣x^−X∣∣≤ϵℓ(yg(x^))⇔max⁡∣∣δ∣∣≤ϵ∇xℓ(yg(x))⊤δ\max_{\hat x, ||\hat x- X|| \leq \epsilon} \ell(yg(\hat x)) \Leftrightarrow \max_{||\delta|| \leq \epsilon} \nabla_x \ell(yg(x))^\top \deltamaxx^,∣∣x^−X∣∣≤ϵ​ℓ(yg(x^))⇔max∣∣δ∣∣≤ϵ​∇x​ℓ(yg(x))⊤δ﻿ because g(x+δ)≈g(x)+δ⊤∇xg(x)g(x+\delta) \approx g(x) + \delta^\top\nabla_x g(x)g(x+δ)≈g(x)+δ⊤∇x​g(x)﻿ (Taylor series)

White box attacks: model ggg﻿ is known

  • compute gradient ∇xℓ\nabla_x \ell∇x​ℓ﻿ during back-propagation to move in the direction opposite to the right classification
  • one-step attack:
    • ℓ2\ell_2ℓ2​﻿ norm: x^=x−ϵy∇xg(x)∣∣∇xg(x)∣∣2\hat x = x-\epsilon y \frac{\nabla_x g(x)}{||\nabla_x g(x)||_2}x^=x−ϵy∣∣∇x​g(x)∣∣2​∇x​g(x)​﻿
    • ℓ∞\ell_\inftyℓ∞​﻿ norm: x^=x−ϵy⋅sign(∇xg(x))\hat x = x-\epsilon y \cdot \text{sign}(\nabla_x g(x))x^=x−ϵy⋅sign(∇x​g(x))﻿
  • multi-step attack: Projected Gradient Descent (PGD): iteratively update δ\deltaδ﻿ and project back on the feasible set ∣∣δ∣∣≤ϵ||\delta||\leq \epsilon∣∣δ∣∣≤ϵ﻿
    • ℓ2\ell_2ℓ2​﻿ norm: δt+1=ΠB2(ϵ)[δt+α∇ℓ~(x+δt)∣∣∇ℓ~(x+δt)∣∣2]\delta^{t+1} = \Pi_{B_2(\epsilon)} \left[\delta^t+\alpha \frac{\nabla \tilde \ell (x+ \delta^t)}{||\nabla \tilde \ell (x+ \delta^t)||_2} \right]δt+1=ΠB2​(ϵ)​[δt+α∣∣∇ℓ~(x+δt)∣∣2​∇ℓ~(x+δt)​]﻿
      with
      ΠB2(ϵ)(δ)={ϵ⋅δ/∣∣δ∣∣2if ∣∣δ∣∣2≥ϵδotherwise\Pi_{B_2(\epsilon)}(\delta) = \begin{cases}\epsilon \cdot \delta/||\delta||_2 & \text{if } ||\delta||_2 \geq \epsilon \\ \delta & \text{otherwise}\end{cases} ΠB2​(ϵ)​(δ)={ϵ⋅δ/∣∣δ∣∣2​δ​if ∣∣δ∣∣2​≥ϵotherwise​﻿
    • ℓ∞\ell_\inftyℓ∞​﻿ norm: δt+1=ΠB∞(ϵ)[δt+α⋅sign(∇ℓ~(x+δt))]\delta^{t+1} = \Pi_{B_\infty(\epsilon)} \left[\delta^t+\alpha \cdot \text{sign}( \nabla \tilde \ell (x+ \delta^t)) \right]δt+1=ΠB∞​(ϵ)​[δt+α⋅sign(∇ℓ~(x+δt))]﻿
      with
      ΠB∞(ϵ)(δ)i={ϵ⋅sign(δi)if ∣δi∣≥ϵδiotherwise\Pi_{B_\infty(\epsilon)}(\delta)_i = \begin{cases}\epsilon \cdot \text{sign}(\delta_i) & \text{if } |\delta_i| \geq \epsilon \\ \delta_i & \text{otherwise}\end{cases} ΠB∞​(ϵ)​(δ)i​={ϵ⋅sign(δi​)δi​​if ∣δi​∣≥ϵotherwise​﻿

Black box attacks: model ggg﻿ unknown

  • score-based: we can query model scores g(x)g(x)g(x)﻿ → approximate gradient using finite difference
  • decision-based: we can query only prediction f(x)f(x)f(x)﻿
  • transfer attacks: train f^≈f\hat f \approx ff^​≈f﻿ on similar data → transfer white box (f^\hat ff^​﻿) attack on fff﻿
    Query with unlabelled data to obtain
    {xn,f(xn)}\{x_n, f(x_n)\}{xn​,f(xn​)}﻿ → model stealing

Create robust models:

  • Minimise the adversarial risk → train model on best adversarial example x^n∗\hat x_n^*x^n∗​﻿
  • increased computational time + robustness/accuracy tradeoff (non-robust feature may be more accurate but can have high adversarial risk while robust has less than ideal accuracy but better resistance to attacks)
17. Ethics and fairness

No fairness through unawareness! Minorities may be underrepresented → high error rates for minorities (because we aim to avoid overfitting).

Consider we have data XXX﻿, outcome variables YYY﻿ and a score function R=r(X)R=r(X)R=r(X)﻿ that allows to make classification decisions D=1R>tD=1_{R>t}D=1R>t​﻿. Furthermore, let AAA﻿ be a RV that encodes membership status in a protected class.

D=0D=0D=0﻿D=1D=1D=1﻿
Y=0Y=0Y=0﻿True negative
Probability
1−α1-\alpha1−α﻿		Type I error
False positive
Probability
α\alphaα﻿
Y=1Y=1Y=1﻿Type II error
False negative
Probability
β\betaβ﻿		True positive
Probability
1−β1-\beta1−β﻿
  • TPR=P(D=1∣Y=1)\text{TPR} = \mathbb{P}(D=1|Y=1)TPR=P(D=1∣Y=1)﻿
  • FPR=P(D=1∣Y=0)\text{FPR} = \mathbb{P}(D=1|Y=0)FPR=P(D=1∣Y=0)﻿
  • FNR=P(D=0∣Y=1)\text{FNR} = \mathbb{P}(D=0|Y=1)FNR=P(D=0∣Y=1)﻿
  • TNR=P(D=0∣Y=0)\text{TNR} = \mathbb{P}(D=0|Y=0)TNR=P(D=0∣Y=0)﻿

Fairness criteria: equalise statistical quantities involving two groups a,b∈a,b \ina,b∈﻿ AAA﻿

  • Independence: R⊥AR \perp AR⊥A﻿
    • Acceptance rate (decision DDD﻿) does not depend on group AAA﻿
    • P(D=1∣A=a)=P(D=1∣A=b)\mathbb{P}(D=1|A=a)=\mathbb{P}(D=1|A=b)P(D=1∣A=a)=P(D=1∣A=b)﻿
    • Counting both true and false positive decisions, but should not compare them!
  • Separation: R⊥A∣YR \perp A | YR⊥A∣Y﻿
    • Post-hoc criterion, but compares by label
    • FPR(a)=P(D=1∣Y=0,A=a)=FPR(b)\text{FPR}(a) = \mathbb{P}(D=1|Y=0, A=a) = \text{FPR}(b)FPR(a)=P(D=1∣Y=0,A=a)=FPR(b)﻿
    • FNR(a)=FNR(b)\text{FNR}(a) = \text{FNR}(b)FNR(a)=FNR(b)﻿
  • Sufficiency: Y⊥A∣RY \perp A|RY⊥A∣R﻿
    • Meaning for predicting YYY﻿ we do not need to know AAA﻿ if we have RRR﻿
    • P(Y=1∣R=r,A=a)=P(Y=1∣R=r,A=b)\mathbb{P}(Y=1|R=r, A=a) = \mathbb{P}(Y=1|R=r, A=b)P(Y=1∣R=r,A=a)=P(Y=1∣R=r,A=b)﻿
    • Calibrated by group, i.e. P(Y=1∣R=r,A=a)=r\mathbb{P}(Y=1|R=r, A=a) = rP(Y=1∣R=r,A=a)=r﻿ implies sufficiency
  • Any of these criteria are mutually exclusive!
    • Independence vs. sufficiency: A⊥RA \perp RA⊥R﻿ and A⊥Y∣R⇒A⊥(Y,R)⇒A⊥YA \perp Y|R \Rightarrow A \perp (Y,R) \Rightarrow A \perp YA⊥Y∣R⇒A⊥(Y,R)⇒A⊥Y﻿
    • Independence vs. separation: A⊥RA \perp RA⊥R﻿ and A⊥R∣Y⇒A⊥YA \perp R|Y \Rightarrow A \perp YA⊥R∣Y⇒A⊥Y﻿ or R⊥YR \perp YR⊥Y﻿
    • Separation vs. sufficiency: A⊥R∣YA \perp R|YA⊥R∣Y﻿ and A⊥Y∣R⇒A⊥(R,Y)A \perp Y|R \Rightarrow A \perp (R,Y)A⊥Y∣R⇒A⊥(R,Y)﻿
18. Unsupervised learning

Representation learning (encoder x↦ϕ(x)x \mapsto \phi(x)x↦ϕ(x)﻿)

Density estimation & generative models (decoder ϕ(x)↦x\phi(x) \mapsto xϕ(x)↦x﻿)

19. K-Means Clustering, Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM)

K-Means Clustering

Objective:

  • For all NNN﻿ data vectors xn∈RDx_n \in \R^Dxn​∈RD﻿: find cluster means μ1,...,μK\mu_1, ..., \mu_Kμ1​,...,μK​﻿ and cluster assignments znk={1if xn∈clusterK0if xn∉clusterK∈RDz_{nk} = \begin{cases} 1 & \text{if } x_n \in \text{cluster} K \\ 0 & \text{if } x_n \notin \text{cluster} K \end{cases} \in \R^Dznk​={10​if xn​∈clusterKif xn​∈/clusterK​∈RD﻿
  • Assuming KK K﻿ is known, we are searching min⁡z,μL(z,μ)=∑N∑Kznk∣∣xn−μk∣∣22\min_{z, \mu} \mathcal{L}(z, \mu) = \sum^N \sum^K z_{nk} ||x_n-\mu_k||^2_2minz,μ​L(z,μ)=∑N∑Kznk​∣∣xn​−μk​∣∣22​﻿

Algorithm: Initialise μk\mu_k μk​﻿ ∀k\forall k∀k﻿, then

  1. For all nnn﻿ compute znz_n zn​﻿ given μ\mu μ﻿ (cost O(NKD)\mathcal{O}(NKD)O(NKD)﻿) → z(t+1):=argmin⁡zL(z,μ(t))z^{(t+1)}:=\text{arg} \min_z \mathcal{L}(z, \mu^{(t)})z(t+1):=argminz​L(z,μ(t))﻿

    znk={1if k=argmin⁡j∣∣xn−μj∣∣220otherwisez_{nk} = \begin{cases} 1 & \text{if } k = \text{arg} \min_j ||x_n-\mu_j||^2_2 \\ 0 & \text{otherwise}\end{cases} znk​={10​if k=argminj​∣∣xn​−μj​∣∣22​otherwise​﻿
  1. For all kkk﻿ compute the group means μk\mu_kμk​﻿ given zzz﻿ (cost O(NKD)\mathcal{O}(NKD)O(NKD)﻿)

    → μ(t+1):=argmin⁡μL(z(t),μ)\mu^{(t+1)}:=\text{arg} \min_\mu \mathcal{L}(z^{(t)}, \mu)μ(t+1):=argminμ​L(z(t),μ)﻿ and μk=∑Nznkxn∑Nznk\mu_k = \frac{\sum^N z_{nk}x_n}{\sum^N z_{nk}}μk​=∑Nznk​∑Nznk​xn​​﻿

  1. Repeat until there is no more change in assignment → no more change of the μk\mu_kμk​﻿

→ Convergence to a local optimum is assured since each step decreases the cost



K-means as matrix factorisation:

min⁡z,μL(z,μ)=∑N∑Kznk∣∣xn−μk∣∣22=∣∣X⊤−MZ⊤∣∣F2\min_{z, \mu} \mathcal{L}(z, \mu) = \sum^N \sum^K z_{nk} ||x_n-\mu_k||^2_2 = ||\mathbf{X}^\top - \mathbf{MZ}^\top||^2_Fminz,μ​L(z,μ)=∑N∑Kznk​∣∣xn​−μk​∣∣22​=∣∣X⊤−MZ⊤∣∣F2​﻿

The matrix M∈RD×K\mathbf{M} \in \R^{D\times K}M∈RD×K﻿ contains the KK K﻿ mean vectors μK\mu_KμK​﻿ and Z⊤∈RK×N\mathbf{Z^\top} \in \R^{K\times N}Z⊤∈RK×N﻿ contains the NNN﻿ assignment vectors. Convex in M\mathbf{M} M﻿ and Z\mathbf{Z}Z﻿ but not jointly convex.

Frobenius norm: ∣∣A∣∣F=∑M∑N∣amn∣2=tr(A∗A)||A||_F = \sqrt{\sum^M \sum^N |a_{mn}|^2} = \sqrt{\text{tr}(A^*A)}∣∣A∣∣F​=∑M∑N∣amn​∣2​=tr(A∗A)​﻿

Gaussian Mixture Models

  • Elliptical clusters and soft-assignment
  • Bayes’ Law: p(a,b)=p(a∣b)p(b)p(a, b)=p(a|b)p(b)p(a,b)=p(a∣b)p(b)﻿
  • Multivariate normal distribution

    f(x;μ,Σ)=1(2π)k/2∣Σ∣1/2exp⁡(−12(x−μ)TΣ−1(x−μ))f(\mathbf{x};\mathbf{\mu},\mathbf{\Sigma}) = \frac{1}{(2\pi)^{k/2}|\mathbf{\Sigma}|^{1/2}} \exp\left(-\frac{1}{2}(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{\mu})^T\mathbf{\Sigma}^{-1}(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{\mu})\right)f(x;μ,Σ)=(2π)k/2∣Σ∣1/21​exp(−21​(x−μ)TΣ−1(x−μ))﻿
  • Added Σ∈RD2×K\Sigma \in \R^{D^2 \times K}Σ∈RD2×K﻿ (covariance matrices) and Π∈RK\Pi \in \R^KΠ∈RK﻿ (cluster probabilities) such that p(zn=k)=πkp(z_n = k) = \pi_kp(zn​=k)=πk​﻿ where πk>0\pi_k > 0 πk​>0﻿ for all kk k﻿ and ∑k=1Kπk=1\sum_{k=1}^{K} \pi_k =1∑k=1K​πk​=1﻿

    → New parameters θ={μ1,...,μK,Σ1,...,ΣK,π}\theta = \{\mu_1, ..., \mu_K, \Sigma_1, ..., \Sigma_K, \pi\}θ={μ1​,...,μK​,Σ1​,...,ΣK​,π}﻿

  • marginal likelihood p(xn∣θ)=∑k=1KπkN(xn∣μk,Σk)p(x_n|\theta)=\sum_{k=1}^K\pi_k \mathcal{N}(x_n|\mu_k, \Sigma_k)p(xn​∣θ)=∑k=1K​πk​N(xn​∣μk​,Σk​)﻿ → O(D2K)\mathcal{O}(D^2K) O(D2K)﻿ parameters left
  • Searching θ∗=argmax⁡θ∑n=1Nlog⁡∑k=1KπkN(xn∣μk,Σk)\theta^* = \text{arg}\max_\theta \sum_{n=1}^N\log\sum_{k=1}^K \pi_k\mathcal{N}(x_n|\mu_k, \Sigma_k)θ∗=argmaxθ​∑n=1N​log∑k=1K​πk​N(xn​∣μk​,Σk​)﻿
    • Not convex, not identifiable (permutation), not bounded (σ→0)\sigma \rightarrow 0)σ→0)﻿

Expectation-Maximisation (EM) algorithm

  • In short: θ(t+1):=argmax⁡θ∑n=1NEp(zn∣xn,θ(t))[log⁡p(xn,zn∣θ)]\theta^{(t+1)}:= \text{arg}\max_\theta \sum_{n=1}^N \mathbb{E}_{p(z_n|x_n, \theta^{(t)})}[\log p(x_n, z_n|\theta)]θ(t+1):=argmaxθ​∑n=1N​Ep(zn​∣xn​,θ(t))​[logp(xn​,zn​∣θ)]﻿
  • Expectation step: find lower bound L‾\underline{\mathcal{L}}L​﻿ such that L(θ)≥L‾(θ,θ(t))\mathcal{L}(\theta) \geq \underline{\mathcal{L}}(\theta, \theta^{(t)})L(θ)≥L​(θ,θ(t))﻿ and L(θ(t))=L‾(θ(t),θ(t))\mathcal{L}(\theta^{(t)}) = \underline{\mathcal{L}}(\theta^{(t)}, \theta^{(t)})L(θ(t))=L​(θ(t),θ(t))﻿
    • Concavity of log: Jensen’s inequality: log⁡(∑k=1Kqkrk)≥∑k=1Kqklog⁡rk\log \left(\sum_{k=1}^K q_kr_k\right) \geq \sum_{k=1}^K q_k\log r_klog(∑k=1K​qk​rk​)≥∑k=1K​qk​logrk​﻿ for rk>0r_k >0 rk​>0﻿ and ∑kqk=1\sum_k q_k = 1∑k​qk​=1﻿
    • Jensen’s inequality with qk=πk(t)N(xn∣μk(t),Σk(t))∑k=1Kπk(t)N(xn∣μk(t),Σk(t))q_k = \frac{\pi_k^{(t)} \mathcal{N}(x_n|\mu_k^{(t)}, \Sigma_k^{(t)})}{\sum_{k=1}^K\pi_k^{(t)} \mathcal{N}(x_n|\mu_k^{(t)}, \Sigma_k^{(t)})}qk​=∑k=1K​πk(t)​N(xn​∣μk(t)​,Σk(t)​)πk(t)​N(xn​∣μk(t)​,Σk(t)​)​﻿ and rk=πkN(xn∣μk,Σk)qkr_k = \frac{\pi_k \mathcal{N}(x_n|\mu_k, \Sigma_k)}{q_k}rk​=qk​πk​N(xn​∣μk​,Σk​)​﻿
  • Maximisation step:
    • θ(t+1)=argmax⁡θL‾(θ,θ(t))\theta^{(t+1)}=\text{arg}\max_\theta \underline{\mathcal{L}}(\theta, \theta^{(t)})θ(t+1)=argmaxθ​L​(θ,θ(t))﻿
    • μk(t+1):=∑nqkn(t)xn∑nqkn(t)\mu_k^{(t+1)}:=\frac{\sum_n q_{kn}^{(t)} x_n}{\sum_n q_{kn}^{(t)}}μk(t+1)​:=∑n​qkn(t)​∑n​qkn(t)​xn​​﻿
    • Σk(t+1):=∑nqkn(t)(xn−μk(t+1))(xn−μk(t+1))⊤∑nqkn(t)\Sigma_k^{(t+1)}:=\frac{\sum_n q_{kn}^{(t)} (x_n-\mu_k^{(t+1)})(x_n-\mu_k^{(t+1)})^\top}{\sum_n q_{kn}^{(t)}}Σk(t+1)​:=∑n​qkn(t)​∑n​qkn(t)​(xn​−μk(t+1)​)(xn​−μk(t+1)​)⊤​﻿
    • πk(t+1):=1N∑nqkn(t)\pi_k^{(t+1)}:=\frac{1}{N}\sum_n q_{kn}^{(t)}πk(t+1)​:=N1​∑n​qkn(t)​﻿
  • Posterior distribution:
    • p(xn,zn∣θ)=p(xn∣zn,θ)p(zn∣θ)=p(zn∣xn,θ)p(xn∣θ)p(x_n, z_n|\theta) = p(x_n| z_n,\theta)p(z_n|\theta) = p(z_n | x_n,\theta)p(x_n|\theta)p(xn​,zn​∣θ)=p(xn​∣zn​,θ)p(zn​∣θ)=p(zn​∣xn​,θ)p(xn​∣θ)﻿
    • joint=likelihood⋅prior=posterior⋅marginal likelihood\text{joint} = \text{likelihood} \cdot \text{prior} = \text{posterior} \cdot \text{marginal likelihood}joint=likelihood⋅prior=posterior⋅marginal likelihood﻿
    • joint=N(xn∣μk,Σk)⋅πk=qkn⋅∑k=1KπkN(xn∣μk,Σk)\text{joint} = \mathcal{N}(x_n|\mu_k, \Sigma_k) \cdot \pi_k = q_{kn} \cdot \sum_{k=1}^K\pi_k \mathcal{N}(x_n|\mu_k, \Sigma_k)joint=N(xn​∣μk​,Σk​)⋅πk​=qkn​⋅∑k=1K​πk​N(xn​∣μk​,Σk​)﻿
20. Matrix factorisations

Aim to find W∈RD×K\mathbf{W} \in \R^{D\times K}W∈RD×K﻿ (e.g. movies) and Z⊤∈RK×N\mathbf{Z^\top} \in \R^{K\times N}Z⊤∈RK×N﻿ (e.g. users) such that X≈WZ⊤\mathbf{X}\approx \mathbf{WZ}^\topX≈WZ⊤﻿, where each user and movie are described by a vector in RK\R^KRK﻿ and xdnx_{dn}xdn​﻿ such that (d,n)∈Ω(d,n)\in\Omega(d,n)∈Ω﻿ contains the existing rating of user nn n﻿ for movie ddd﻿ (K≪D,N)(K\ll D,N)(K≪D,N)﻿. We are minimising:

Regularisation (not matrix factorisation anymore): add λw2∣∣W∣∣F2\frac{\lambda_w}{2}||\mathbf{W}||^2_F2λw​​∣∣W∣∣F2​﻿ or λz2∣∣Z∣∣F2\frac{\lambda_z}{2}||\mathbf{Z}||^2_F2λz​​∣∣Z∣∣F2​﻿, λw,λz>0\lambda_w, \lambda_z>0λw​,λz​>0﻿

SGD:

  • For a fixed element (d,n)(d,n)(d,n)﻿:

    ∂Ldn∂wd′,k(W,Z)={−[xdn−(WZ⊤)dn]zn,kif d′=d0otherwise∈RK\frac{\partial \mathcal{L}_{dn}}{\partial w_{d',k}}(\mathbf{W,Z}) = \begin{cases} -[x_{dn}-(\mathbf{WZ}^\top)_{dn}]z_{n,k} & \text{if } d'=d \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases} \in \R^K∂wd′,k​∂Ldn​​(W,Z)={−[xdn​−(WZ⊤)dn​]zn,k​0​if d′=dotherwise​∈RK﻿

    ∂Ldn∂zn′,k(W,Z)={−[xdn−(WZ⊤)dn]wd,kif n′=n0otherwise∈RK\frac{\partial \mathcal{L}_{dn}}{\partial z_{n',k}}(\mathbf{W,Z}) = \begin{cases} -[x_{dn}-(\mathbf{WZ}^\top)_{dn}]w_{d,k} & \text{if } n'=n \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases} \in \R^K∂zn′,k​∂Ldn​​(W,Z)={−[xdn​−(WZ⊤)dn​]wd,k​0​if n′=notherwise​∈RK﻿

Alternating Least Squares (ALS):

  • Assuming no missing entries. First update Z\mathbf{Z}Z﻿ with fixed W\mathbf{W}W﻿ then W\mathbf{W}W﻿with fixed Z\mathbf{Z}Z﻿
  • Z⊤:=(W⊤W+λzIK)−1W⊤X\mathbf{Z}^\top:=(\mathbf{W}^\top\mathbf{W}+ \lambda_z\mathbf{I}_K)^{-1}\mathbf{W}^\top\mathbf{X}Z⊤:=(W⊤W+λz​IK​)−1W⊤X﻿
  • W⊤:=(Z⊤Z+λwIK)−1Z⊤X\mathbf{W}^\top:=(\mathbf{Z}^\top\mathbf{Z}+ \lambda_w\mathbf{I}_K)^{-1}\mathbf{Z}^\top\mathbf{X}W⊤:=(Z⊤Z+λw​IK​)−1Z⊤X﻿
21. Text representation learning

Use log of co-occurence counts of words wdw_dwd​﻿ and context words wnw_nwn​﻿ → sparse matrix ∈ND×N\in \N^{D \times N}∈ND×N﻿

  • Same objective as matrix factorisations, except for adding a weighting term fdnf_{dn} fdn​﻿ in the sum. For GloVe, we have fdn:=min⁡{1,(ndnnmax)α}f_{dn}:=\min\{1, (\frac{n_{dn}}{n_{max}})^\alpha\}fdn​:=min{1,(nmax​ndn​​)α}﻿ for α∈[0,1]\alpha\in [0, 1]α∈[0,1]﻿
  • Rows of W∈RD×K\mathbf{W} \in \R^{D\times K}W∈RD×K﻿ and Z∈RN×K\mathbf{Z} \in \R^{N\times K}Z∈RN×K﻿ are word (or context word) representations
  • Skip-Gram model (word2vec): use binary classification to separate real word pairs (wd,wn)(w_d, w_n)(wd​,wn​)﻿ (appearing together in context window size 5) from fake word paris (random words)
  • FastText: matrix factorisation to learn sentence sns_nsn​﻿ representations (supervised (sn,yn)(s_n,y_n)(sn​,yn​)﻿). yn∈{−1,1}y_n \in \{-1, 1\}yn​∈{−1,1}﻿ and ff f﻿ is a linear classifier loss, xnx_nxn​﻿ the bag-of-words (no ordering!) representation of sns_nsn​﻿. Minimising
22. Self-supervised learning

Use pretext tasks f:xin↦xoutf:\mathbf{x}_{in} \mapsto \mathbf{x}_{out}f:xin​↦xout​﻿ that learn from unlabelled data with a function g:x↦(xin,xout)g: \mathbf{x} \mapsto(\mathbf{x}_{in}, \mathbf{x}_{out})g:x↦(xin​,xout​)﻿ that creates the data (e.g. predict image rotation, relative patch placement) → only need to corrupt data to create training pairs

Masked Language Modelling (MLM): predict hidden word [MASK]

  • Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT): Encoder only, can look at both previous and following tokens. Pretext tasks: 1.predict original masked token 2. predict whether second sentence immediately follows first sentence [CLS] . Fine-tuned for sentiment prediction, noun/verb prediction, find start/end of passage.
  • Next token prediction - Generative Pre-trained Transformers (GPT): Decoder only, can look only at prior tokens (masked attention). Auto-regressive → uses previous output to compute loss (softmax cross-entropy) for next output. Fine-tuned for in-context learning or instruction following.
  • Joint Embedding Methods: Learn encoder invariants (e.g. rotations) by creating views (rotations, distorsions) of an original image
  • Contrastive learning: positive pair x,x+\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}^+x,x+﻿ and negative view x−\mathbf{x}^-x−﻿ → s(f(x),f(x+))>s(f(x),f(x−))s(f(\mathbf{x}), f(\mathbf{x}^+)) > s(f(\mathbf{x}), f(\mathbf{x}^-))s(f(x),f(x+))>s(f(x),f(x−))﻿, where sss﻿ is a similarity function (e.g. cosine similarity)
    • SimCLR:
      1. classification with NNN﻿ negative samples
      1. map encoder output to the similarity f(x)=f2∘f1(x)f(\mathbf{x})=f_2 \circ f_1(\mathbf{x})f(x)=f2​∘f1​(x)﻿ use only f1f_1 f1​﻿ for downstream tasks
      1. use cosine similarity with temperature scaling τ:s(e1,e2)=⟨e1,e2⟩∣∣e1∣∣2∣∣e2∣∣2/τ\tau: s(\mathbf{e}_1, \mathbf{e}_2)=\frac{\langle\mathbf{e}_1, \mathbf{e}_2 \rangle}{||\mathbf{e}_1||_2||\mathbf{e}_2||_2}/\tauτ:s(e1​,e2​)=∣∣e1​∣∣2​∣∣e2​∣∣2​⟨e1​,e2​⟩​/τ﻿
      1. generate views with data augmentation
    • CLIP: captioned images to learn a joint multimodal embedding space
23. Generative Models

Creates more form the learned distribution p(x)p(x)p(x)﻿. Explicit → learn distribution. Implicit → only generating samples according to distribution.

Generative Adversarial Networks: Create images from known noise distribution pzp_zpz​﻿. 2-player game: generator G(θ)G(\theta)G(θ)﻿ vs. discriminator D(φ)D(\varphi)D(φ)﻿ (deep NNs). TTT﻿ steps gradient descent for steps

  1. φ∗∈argmin⁡φ∈ΦLφ(θ∗,φ)\varphi^*\in\text{arg} \min_{\varphi \in \Phi} \mathcal{L}^\varphi(\theta^*, \varphi)φ∗∈argminφ∈Φ​Lφ(θ∗,φ)﻿ → distinguishes real (x∼pdx \sim p_dx∼pd​﻿) vs. generated images G(z)G(z)G(z)﻿
  1. θ∗∈argmin⁡θ∈ΘLθ(θ,φ∗)\theta^*\in\text{arg} \min_{\theta \in \Theta} \mathcal{L}^\theta(\theta, \varphi^*)θ∗∈argminθ∈Θ​Lθ(θ,φ∗)﻿ → creates realistic images G(z)G(z)G(z)﻿
  1. Objective: min⁡Gmax⁡DEx∼pd[log⁡D(x)]+Ez∼pz[log⁡(1−D(G(z)))]\min_G \max_D \mathbb{E}_{x \sim p_d}[\log D(x)] + \mathbb{E}_{z \sim p_z}[\log (1-D(G(z)))]minG​maxD​Ex∼pd​​[logD(x)]+Ez∼pz​​[log(1−D(G(z)))]﻿
  1. Theoretical solution: optimum when pg=pdp_g = p_d pg​=pd​﻿ with value −log⁡4- \log4−log4﻿

→ Conditional GAN (CGAN): additional information ccc﻿ (e.g. class labels)

Diffusion models: forward decomposition → add noise, backward decomposition → undo noise Use ancestral sampling starting from a pure Gaussian noise and denoising using Markov chain. Often use U-net architecture (with exponential moving average to stabilise training) with ResNet blocks and self-attention layers. To add additional information yyy﻿ (conditional training), the probabilities of neural net sθs_\thetasθ​﻿ should be conditional on YYY﻿.
